column4: I have a couple of ext4 partitions, where if I right click on them in ubuntu, and check the permissions, they only show "root" as the user and no other options. I cannot write to these partitions. Can anyone tell me how to correct this?
add them in /etc/fstab and set better access
chown -R    for recursive
sudo chown -R $USER:$USER /mount/point      not the block device
maybe I'm confused about what you mean by mount point. Is /dev/sdc1 not a mount point?
no /dev/sdc1 is the block device, you mount the block device and you can access the data etc, you manipulate that
edit /etc/samba/smb.conf
Do I have to have samba installed for this?
its in the default install (no samba)
ok, the the reason I asked is because I was trying to restart the service without having to restart Ubuntu, but all of the commands I was able to find had to do with samba, which I don't have
hybrid GPU is problematic in Linux
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/HybridGraphics
add the boot option:   text
where do I add this? grub?

gksudo gedit /etc/default/grub   change this line:  GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet splash"    to      GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet splash text"     save the new file, close gedit and run:  sudo update-grub
press ALT+F2 and run:  nautilus
doing that opens up my home directory. I forgot to mention, my home directory came up on startup.
look in /usr/share/xsessions   read the exec line
xubuntu.desktop shows the exec to be startxfce4. Unfortunately, startxfce4 starts the xfce session.
no options and such?
I'm not sure what you mean by options. But both xubuntu.desktop and xfce.desktop show exec=startxfce4, which nothing else after it
dang
